title: Progressive Multifocal Leukoencephalopathy (PML)
scope: ** Diagnosis and management of PML in all clinical contexts: HIV-associated, natalizumab-associated, other immunosuppression-associated, and rare immunocompetent PML. Covers CSF JCV PCR testing, MRI features, immune reconstitution strategies, PML-IRIS management, and supportive care. Excludes other causes of leukoencephalopathy as primary diagnosis but includes in differential.

Core Labs (All Patients).rationale: HIV is most common cause of PML; must test all patients
If HIV positive: quantify viral burden; guide ART initiation
Degree of immunosuppression; PML typically occurs with CD4 <200 in HIV; also useful in non-HIV immunosuppression
Risk stratification; high index (>1.5) associated with greater PML risk in natalizumab patients; documents JCV exposure
Core Labs (All Patients).target: Negative or low index (<0.9 lower risk)

Extended Labs.rationale: Characterize immune deficiency; guide immune reconstitution strategy
Hypogammaglobulinemia from rituximab or other B-cell depleting therapy

Extended Labs.rationale: Prognostic marker; elevated associated with worse outcomes

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Assess immune reconstitution; guide treatment in PML-IRIS

Lumbar Puncture.target: Negative (positive confirms PML in appropriate clinical/imaging context); higher copy numbers = worse prognosis

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Typically normal in PML; elevated WBC suggests IRIS or alternative diagnosis
Lumbar Puncture.target: Normal (<5 WBC); elevated with lymphocytic predominance suggests PML-IRIS
Normal or mildly elevated (typically <100 mg/dL); markedly elevated suggests alternative

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: MS evaluation if natalizumab patient; baseline
Lumbar Puncture.target: Variable; may be present from underlying MS

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Exclude lymphoma (may mimic PML on imaging)

Essential Studies.target: Multifocal, bilateral, asymmetric subcortical/juxtacortical white matter T2/FLAIR hyperintensities; typically NO enhancement and NO mass effect (distinguishes from tumors); involves subcortical U-fibers; posterior fossa common

Essential Studies.timing: Only if MRI not immediately available
Essential Studies.target: Hypodense white matter lesions; less sensitive than MRI

Extended Studies.timing: Serial monitoring for progression or IRIS; every 4-8 weeks initially
Extended Studies.target: Stabilization or improvement of lesions; new enhancement suggests PML-IRIS

Extended Studies.timing: Differentiate PML from other white matter diseases
Extended Studies.target: Reduced NAA (neuronal loss); elevated choline (demyelination); elevated myo-inositol

Extended Studies.timing: If seizures occur; encephalopathy assessment; outpatient monitoring for subclinical seizures
Extended Studies.target: Focal or diffuse slowing; epileptiform activity at lesion borders

Acute/Emergent.indication: HIV-associated PML; ART is the ONLY proven effective treatment; immune reconstitution allows immune clearance of JCV

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology consultation for PML diagnosis confirmation, IRIS management, and serial monitoring
Infectious disease consultation for HIV-PML (ART optimization) and non-HIV immunosuppression management
Neuroradiology review for MRI pattern characterization and serial imaging comparison
Physical therapy for motor rehabilitation, mobility assessment, and adaptive equipment
Occupational therapy for ADL assessment, adaptive strategies for visual and motor deficits
Speech therapy for aphasia, dysarthria, and dysphagia assessment
Neuropsychology referral for formal cognitive assessment and rehabilitation planning
Palliative care for goals of care discussion, symptom management, and advance care planning given poor prognosis in many cases
Social work consult for insurance navigation, disability resources, home care coordination, and support services
Neurosurgery consultation only if brain biopsy needed for diagnosis (CSF JCV PCR negative with high clinical suspicion)

Patient Instructions.item: Return to ED immediately for rapid neurological decline (new weakness, vision loss, speech difficulty, sudden confusion, seizures), as PML can progress rapidly and treatment adjustments may be needed
Do NOT stop antiretroviral therapy (if HIV-positive) under any circumstances; ART is the single most important treatment for HIV-PML; missed doses reduce effectiveness
Understand that worsening after starting ART (HIV) or stopping natalizumab may represent IRIS — a paradoxical inflammatory response that is expected and treatable; do not stop ART if this occurs
Seizure precautions: avoid driving until seizure risk assessed by neurology; do not swim or bathe alone; remove sharp/hard hazards from home; fall precautions
Take all anti-seizure medications as prescribed; do not skip doses or stop abruptly; missed doses increase seizure risk
Follow-up appointments and MRIs are critical — do not miss scheduled imaging, as PML requires close monitoring for progression and IRIS
Report any new fever, headache, or worsening symptoms during steroid taper, as this may indicate IRIS flare requiring dose adjustment
Carry a medical identification card or bracelet listing PML diagnosis, current medications, and emergency contact for neurology

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: For patients on natalizumab: JCV antibody index monitoring q6 months; discuss treatment switch with MS specialist if JCV index >1.5 and treatment duration >24 months
Maximize antiretroviral adherence to maintain immune function and prevent PML recurrence/progression; use pill organizers, alarms, or directly observed therapy if needed
Home safety modifications for visual field deficits, weakness, and cognitive impairment: remove trip hazards, improve lighting, install grab bars, consider stair gates
Advance care planning discussions early given variable but often poor prognosis; designate healthcare proxy; document code status and treatment preferences
Infection avoidance: hand hygiene, avoid sick contacts, avoid raw/undercooked foods; immunocompromised patients at higher risk for opportunistic infections
Nutrition optimization: adequate protein and caloric intake; consult dietitian if weight loss or poor appetite; address swallowing difficulties if present
Caregiver education: teach recognition of seizures, IRIS symptoms, and neurological decline; ensure caregiver knows when to call 911 vs. neurology clinic

differential.features: Periventricular enhancing lesions; homogeneous enhancement; may be multifocal; immunocompromised patients at risk for both
differential.tests: MRI (PML: no enhancement; lymphoma: enhancing); CSF cytology/flow cytometry; brain biopsy

differential.features: Diffuse white matter changes; symmetric; no focal lesions; more gradual cognitive decline
differential.tests: MRI (diffuse vs multifocal); CSF JCV PCR negative; clinical course (slower); HIV viral load correlation

differential.features: In natalizumab patients; new MS lesions vs PML; MS lesions typically periventricular, smaller, enhance
differential.tests: MRI pattern (MS: periventricular, enhancing; PML: subcortical U-fibers, no enhancement); CSF JCV PCR

differential.features: Posterior-predominant vasogenic edema; hypertension; seizures; reversible
differential.tests: MRI (posterior vasogenic edema on ADC; PML: restricted diffusion); clinical context; BP

differential.features: Post-infectious; encephalopathy; large lesions; enhancing; monophasic; responds to steroids
differential.tests: CSF JCV PCR negative; clinical context (post-infectious); MRI (enhancing lesions); steroid-responsive

differential.features: Inflammatory MRI changes on natalizumab cessation without true PML; JCV PCR negative
differential.tests: CSF JCV PCR negative; MRI may show enhancement but no typical PML lesion pattern

differential.features: Ring-enhancing lesions; mass effect; CD4 usually <100; anti-Toxoplasma IgG positive
differential.tests: MRI (ring enhancement, mass effect — not typical of PML); Toxoplasma IgG; response to empiric treatment

differential.features: Periventricular enhancement; cranial neuropathies; polyradiculopathy; CD4 <50
differential.tests: CSF CMV PCR; periventricular enhancement pattern; ependymal involvement

differential.features: Chronic symmetric white matter hyperintensities; vascular risk factors; non-progressive or slowly progressive
differential.tests: MRI (symmetric, chronic-appearing); clinical context (vascular risk factors); no JCV in CSF

evidence.recommendation: CSF JCV PCR is the definitive diagnostic test for PML; sensitivity 72-92%
ART is the primary treatment for HIV-PML; immune reconstitution improves survival
Natalizumab-associated PML: PLEX accelerates drug clearance and immune reconstitution
PML-IRIS occurs in ~15-25% of HIV-PML patients starting ART; corticosteroids are standard treatment
Mirtazapine as adjunctive therapy (5-HT2A antagonism blocks JCV entry): limited clinical evidence
Pembrolizumab (anti-PD-1) for non-HIV PML: case series showing potential benefit
evidence.source: [Cortese I et al. N Engl J Med 2019](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31050378/)

disposition.criteria: All new PML diagnoses; ART initiation/optimization; natalizumab cessation with PLEX; serial neurological monitoring; IRIS management
Severe cerebral edema with herniation risk; status epilepticus; severe IRIS with mass effect; respiratory compromise
Neurologically stable or improving; on appropriate immune reconstitution therapy; seizures controlled; safe home environment; close outpatient follow-up arranged (neurology q2-4 weeks; ID for HIV)
All patients: q2-4 weeks during active disease; MRI q4-8 weeks; transition to q3 months when stable
HIV patients: q2-4 weeks for ART optimization; viral load and CD4 monitoring
